Northumberland Go! Sign in 822946264715438 fb822946264715438 822946264715438 fb822946264715438 "Open navigation drawer" "Close navigation drawer" //Preferences user_preferences login_username login_type manual facebook google theme_mode disability_mode travel_mode recent_places dd-MM-yyyy //Quote Welcome To The North! \nAre you ready to discover what all the buzz is about? //Main string "Let's explore!" //Home string "Home" "Enable the camera to access further features" "Location Nearby!" "Cancel Route" "Nearby" "Results" "Clear" " km away" "Get Directions" "Get Started!" "Snap!" "To see the map" "Recently visited place" "List of your achievements" "Personalise this app" "FAQ page" "Camera Help" //Recent Places string "Recent Places" //Achievement string //Recent Places string "Achievement" "Northumberland Council" "Achievement Help" "Achievement Locked" //Settings string "Settings" "Visual Settings" "Enable Dark Mode" "Device Settings:" "Enable Location" "Enable Camera" "Map Settings" "Disability Access Required" "Default Mode of Transport:" "Walking" "Public Transport" "Car" "Logout" "You have already enabled this setting" "Settings Help" //Help string "Help" //Tutorial string "Tutorial" "More" //Map Tutorial You can search for locations using the search bar: \n- You can use #all to show all locations \n- You could type #castle to show all castles \n- You can find a list of hashtags in the Help Section \n- Press more on a location to view information about it \n- Press get directions to get a route to the location \n- Then press the arrow on the right to view readable directions \n \nIf you click nearby, you will be shown the top 3 closest attraction to you \n \nPress the top right target-like button to centre the map on your location \n \nPress the top left button or swipe from the left to view the Navbar \n \nYou can press the question mark(?) to see help for this section at any time //Camera Help \nIn order to complete your trip and possibly unlock an achievement, make sure your phone is first tilted upright. \n \nThen press the \'Snap\', button. \n \nIf you are eligible for an achievement then you will be given an alert telling you new achievements have been unlocked. //Recent Places Tutorial Here you can see all the locations you have visited/calculated routes for during this session of Northumberland GO! \n \nPress on the locations from here to view more information about them. \n \nThis list of recent places will always be saved, so long as you are signed in. //Achievement Tutorial The Achievements page allows you to see all the achievements in the app. \n \nIf the achievement logo is in colour, you have unlocked this achievement. \nIf it is greyed out, then you still need to unlock it. \n \nPressing on an achievement will show you its achievement card\n \n If you have unlocked the achievement you can share its certificate on Facebook or a link to the certificate using any app you desire. //Settings Tutorial On this page you can personalise the app. \n \n-Enabling dark mode will change the entire apps colour scheme, including the maps. \n-If not already enabled, you can enable your location and camera. \n-If you require disabled access you can restrict locations here. \n-You can also set the default mode of transport used to calculate routes. \n \nThis is the only place you can log out of your account. //Help Tutorial Here is a list of frequently asked questions and their answers. \n \nThis page may give you more information about the app, however for any other questions of information, view our user guide on our website… \n \nhttp://homepages.cs.ncl.ac.uk/2018-19/CSC2022/Team12/website/ //FAQ I am not sure what to do with the app, what do I do? Press the (?) button, found in the top right of every window of the app What happens if I am outside of Northumberland, can I still use the app ? Yes, you can but all the destinations in the app are in Northumberland. How do I find the closest destination near me? Go to the homepage, press the Nearby bar at the bottom of the screen. This will show the top 3 closest locations to you. How do I log out? Go to the Settings option in the side navigation bar. On the bottom of the menu there will be a \'logout\' button. Do I require internet access to use the app? To use the app you need to have mobile data and location services enabled. I have arrived at the destination but the Location Nearby button has not shown up, what do I do? Usually problems like this will be fixed if you restart the app. Also make sure that you have a stable internet connection and location services are still enabled. How do I search for a location by its category? The app will only recognise a search for categories if a \'#\' symbol precedes the search term. E.g. #garden will show all gardens. How do I get directions to a location? To display a route to a location on the map, in either the Near Me section or the Results section after a search, tap the More button next to the location. On the new location page, tap the Get Directions button and a route should display on your map. Note that from here you can drag a panel from the right with more detailed directions. The attraction I’m looking for isn’t showing up in the results? If you are sure you have made no spelling errors in your search terms, type #all into the search bar and check the results shown. #all will display all the locations in our app. We apologise if your attraction is still not showing as this means it is not yet in our database. Will the app make posts on my Facebook/Google? The app will not make any posts to your social media without your knowledge or permission. Social media posts will only be made if you decide to share an achievement from the achievement page. How can I share my progress with friends? When you unlock achievements, a Facebook logo will appear next to the now colourful logo. You can press this to share the achievement logo directly to Facebook. You can also press the share symbol next to this button to share a certificate of your achievement as a link, using any messaging platform you desire. The app is too bright, is there a dark mode? Go to the Settings page, turn the switch next to Enable Dark mode on and the app theme will change immediately. Where can I leave feedback and suggestions? Any feedback or suggestions are welcome. Contact us information can be found on our website at
http://homepages.cs.ncl.ac.uk/2018-19/CSC2022/Team12/website/ I no longer want to travel to the attraction I have selected, how do I cancel my route? Press on the arrow on the right hand side of the map screen to bring up the readable directions. At the top of the directions is a Cancel Route button. Press this and the route will disappear. I can only visit attractions with disabled access, is there any help for me? Go to the Settings page, turn the switch next to Disability Access Required on and then only locations that have disabled access will appear on the map/will be searchable. How do I unlock achievements? For location specific achievements, you must travel to the location linked to that achievement. Once you are close the location, press the Location Nearby button, aim your camera at the location and press Snap. This will unlock the achievement. For other achievements, follow the instructions in the achievement description. An achievement isn’t unlocking? Go to the Achievements page and make sure the achievement isn\'t unlocked already (i.e. its logo is in colour). Otherwise try restarting the app and/or completing the achievement criteria again. Is the app also available for iPhones? No, unfortunately at this moment in time Northumberland GO! is only available for android devices. Should I be worried about the data I have given? Even though you have only provided us with your name, email and password, know that your information will be kept safe and never given to anyone. We will also never post anything to social media without your consent and will not require access to any more of your information during the rest of the time you use this app. Do I need to re-enable my custom settings each time I open the app? No, any of your custom settings (such as Dark Mode and your Default Mode of Transport) will be saved and kept active for the next time you log in to the app. What categories of location can I search for using \'#\'? The list of categories you can search by are: toilets, film, tv, parking, food, disability, nature, history, museum, castle, garden and hike. My question isn’t in the FAQ? More help can be found on our user guide listed on our website.
http://homepages.cs.ncl.ac.uk/2018-19/CSC2022/Team12/website/ Is the app endorsed by the attractions? Northumberland Go! is not endorsed by or affiliated with any of the attractions featured. How can I have my business featured on Northumberland Go? Northumberland Go! is made on behalf of Northumberland County Council, who remain neutral and do not promote specific businesses. If you manage a non-profit-making Northumberland attraction, and would like it to be featured on Northumberland Go!, please contact us via the website. //Achievement Welcome To NGO! Sign up to the app I signed up on… Arrived in one piece Arrive at your first ever attraction I visited my first attraction on… Master Explorer Travel to all Locations I visited all the locations on… Junior Explorer Travel to 10 locations I have travelled to 10 locations on… Expedition Take at least an hour to reach a Location on foot I unlocked this achievement on… Speed Runner Reach your target destination in 5 minutes or less I unlocked this achievement on… Lazy Tourist Drive less than a mile to a location I unlocked this achievement on… Late Night Stroll Travel to any Walking Trail between 12am and 5am I unlocked this achievement on History Buff Visit any of the museums I visited a museum on Just fancied a drink Arrive at any pub I visited a pub on That’s what you call a Lake Visit Kielder Water I visited Kielder Water on Northumberland Knight Visit all Castles I have visited all castles on Close but no Cigar Started travelling to a location but abandoned it. I unlocked this achievement on Is this App not good enough? Arrive at a Tourist Information Centre I visited an information center on Are we sure we’re in Northumberland? Visit Newcastle Helix I visited Newcastle Helix on It’s all downhill from here. Visit The Cheviot I visited the Cheviot on You’re a wizard Harry! Visit Alnwick Castle I visited Alnwick Castle on Long time no sea! Visit Lindisfarne I visited the holy island on Walk of the Roses Visit Dunstanburgh Castle I visited Dunstanburgh Castle on What’s your poison? Visit Alnwick Gardens I visited Alnwick gardens on Time to mine! Visit Woodhorn Museum I visited Woodhorn Museum on Turn down for what? Visit Bagpipe Museum I visited Bagpipe Museum on Just going for a short walk. Visit Yeavering Bell I visited Yeavering Bell on That’s a big pet. Visit Whitehouse Farm I visited Whitehouse Farm on Do we have to walk it? Visit Hadrian’s Wall I visited Hadrian’s Wall on "I am married. To England" Visit Bamburgh Castle I visited Bamburgh Castle on Is this mainstream? Visit Haydon’s Bridge I visited Haydon’s Bridge on Fancy a cuppa? Visit Howick Gardens I visited Howick Gardens on //Directions AIzaSyADtlZISmQeiknt61o3xQCXvQE1t1dl6Ng //Database preference Database Connection Error. Code //Main Activity ID Checking Error 1 logRequest true false //Home Activity The Cheviot N/A The highest point in Northumberland, around a mile away from the Scottish border. At a height of 815.3 metres, The Cheviot claims the title as the highest point in the county of northumberland, but is often just referred to as a ‘bog’. However, this gigantic peak has more history than meets the eye. As well as being an age-old extinct volcano, the peak has also played a large part in recent history, acting as the crash site of a Boeing B-17 Bomber during the second world war. Although most of the wreckage has since been removed from the site, there are still some pieces of the aircraft which are visible. Hadrian\'s Wall 128 AD A megastructure which was the former north-west frontier of the roman empire. One of England\'s greatest landmarks, Hadrian\'s Wall stretches 73 miles and still remains strong after being built in 128 AD. It is a UNESCO World Heritage site and is filled with archaeological sites and history from start to finish. The Wall\'s pure stature has inspired popular modern day media such as Game of Thrones, and has always claimed a spot on any list of must-see attractions. Contrary to popular belief, Hadrian\'s Wall does not mark the English/Scottish border. Haydon Bridge 1190 AD A small village situated near major Northumberland attractions with the South Tyne river at its heart. Despite what many people think, Haydon Bridge is not actually a bridge, but instead a small village divided by the South Tyne river. The village is however named after Old Haydon Bridge which was originally erected in the medieval era but replaced in 1776 and has been subject to many repairs over the years. It has now been restricted to pedestrian use and offers beautiful views of the village and river. Haydon Bridge was the birthplace of famous painter John Martin, known for paintings such as The Destruction of Pompeii and Herculaneum and The Plains of Heaven. The luxurious Langley Castle Hotel is just around the corner, making Haydon Village a location packed with history and sites. Alnwick Castle 1096 AD The second largest inhabited castle in the country, used in Films & Television Programmes such as Harry Potter and Downton Abbey. Alnwick Castle is the family home of the Percy’s, or more commonly, the seat of the Duke and Duchess of Northumberland. It has been their family’s home for over 700 years, and has played host to many iconic characters from the big and small screen, such as Harry Potter, The Crawley Family from Downton Abbey, and more recently even Transformers. This has been incorporated into the regular goings on in Alnwick Castle, with Broomstick Lessons and the ‘Dragons’ Quest’ activity suitable for the whole family. The castle has a poisonous garden where a wide range of plants such as nightshade and hemlock grow, supposedly included by the Duchess to educate others about how dangerous plants can be. Parking is £3 if you are driving to this location, and family tickets to gain access to everything the castle has to offer are less than £50. The Holy Island Of Lindisfarne 1550 AD A tidal island featuring medieval ruins, a castle and a nature reserve. Located a few miles from Northumberland’s coast, the holy island is cut off twice a day from the mainland by the tide. The island is home to a quaint village and the ruins of 12th century Lindisfarne Priory, an important hub of Christianity in Anglo-Saxon England. In the rocks at the tip of the island visitors will find Lindisfarne castle. Built in the 16th century, today it is a National Trust site boasting stunning architecture and breathtaking views. As well as plenty of history, the island includes The Lindisfarne National Nature Reserve. This is an area formed by shifting tides and sands combining to form 3500 hectares of saltmarsh, mudflats and dunes. This unique habitat is home to an equally unique combination of wildlife. Bamburgh Castle 420 AD This Grade I listed building was once home to the kings of Northumberland. For a castle, much of the structure is relatively recent. With a history stretching back to approximately the 5th century, the castle was bought and restored in the Victorian era by industrialist Lord Armstrong whose family still owns it to this day. The castle’s majesty has attracted film crews including “Elizabeth” starring Cate Blanchett. Inside the castle there are 14 public rooms containing over 2,000 artefacts. Also inside are a museum, an art gallery, a cafeteria and much more. Outside the castle there’s also a lot to do including trails, cafes and beaches. Frequent archaeological digs are carried out on the site, which everyone can have a go at. Dunstanburgh Castle 1313 AD Castle ruins which once formed the largest and grandest fortifications in Northern England. Construction originally started by Earl Thomas of Lancaster in 1313 as a symbol of his opposition to the monarch, King Edward II. However, Lancaster was defeated in his rebellion and was taken and executed in 1322. The castle was passed on to John of Gaunt who remodelled the twin towered gatehouse into a keep. During the Wars of the Roses, Yorkist forces captured and occupied the castle twice before it deteriorated to its current state. The location offers a great picnic area and links up to coastal walks, which have been ranked within the top 100 walks in the UK. For the not so faint of heart there is a Ghost Walk leading up to the castle where many people believe a knight still haunts the ruins. Kielder Water And Forest Park 1975 AD - 1981 AD A nature park that houses the largest man-made lake in Northern Europe and the largest forest in England. The park features walking trails and bike tracks all across the area for all the family to enjoy. The 26 mile trail, Lakeside Way is perfect for walkers, cyclists, horse riders and wheelchair users who prefer the shoreline of Kielder Water. A popular habitat for wildlife, Kielder Water & Forest Park houses the Kielder Super Six consisting of osprey, pipistrelle bats, roe deer, salmon, deer and red squirrels. Additionally, the park is also the home to around 50% of England’s native red squirrel population. The forest itself is the largest in England, spanning 250 square miles and accounts for a quarter of our timber production. If you decide to stay here past sunset, the magnificent Kielder Observatory will allow you to become an expert stargazer. Alnwick Gardens 1750 AD A contemporary garden including water sculptures and over 4,000 varieties of plant. Conceived by the Duchess of Northumberland, the Alnwick Garden is truly a 21st century public garden, boasting astonishing beauty, traditional symmetry, as well as quirkiness and interaction. The garden stimulates all of the senses, with thousands of seasonal plants and opportunities to cool off in the water sculptures of the Serpent Garden. Those looking for tranquillity can enjoy the Cherry Orchard or Rose Garden, or for more excitement and intrigue there’s the Bamboo Labyrinth and the Poison Garden, where visitors can observe a collection of lethal plants. The wooden Treehouse, which is Europe’s largest, contains a restaurant and has full wheelchair access. Howick Gardens 1400 AD The ancestral seat of the Earls Grey since 1319. Home of Charles 2nd Earl Grey, Prime Minister of the United Kingdom, November 1830 to July 1834. The Howick Hall Gardens were created by the 5th Earl Grey and his family. Voted as the ‘Garden of the Year’ by Garden Museum and Gardens Illustrated magazine in 2009, the gardens have also been featured in BBC Gardeners’ World magazine and The Independent newspaper of best ten gardens to visit in spring. The arboretum, first opened on 1st April 2006 (later with a formal opening by Roy Lancaster on 29th April), expands across 65 acres of land, filled with around 11,000 shrubs and trees from about 1,800 taxa planted in six geographical groups. Woodhorn Museum 1979 AD Houses the Northumberland Archives and acts as a tribute to Woodhorn’s mining heritage. Woodhorn stands as the North East’s last remaining coal mining heritage. At its peak, the local mining site employed 2,000 people underground where a mass of 600,000 tonnes of coal was mined each year. The Cutter Building at the museum, features a notable banner collection and a moving sculpture made up of miner’s gloves, moulded into 98 birds in remembrance of lives lost at Woodhorn Colliery. Woodhorn Museum houses the Ashington Group Collection of artworks also known as the ‘Pitmen Painters’. The exhibition stands as a representation of life for Ashington miners during the 1930s. There is a cafe where parents can relax while their children visit the play area, and four museums in total with over 25,000 objects to keep any history buff satisfied. Bagpipe Museum 1300 AD The Morpeth Chantry Bagpipe Museum exhibits the history and development of bagpipes. The very first bagpipe museum in the UK features a large collection of bagpipes and explores the local history and art of Northumberland through their exhibitions. On display here, there sits an extensive collection of pipes from master clockmaker and pipe enthusiast, William Alfred Cocks, another set of bagpipes that belonged to King Louis XIV, a miniature set made for Queen Mary’s Dolls’ House and also pipes from the Jacobite Rising. Special events and performances are also a key attraction for the museum. The museum’s building has a bit of history in itself, being home to the oldest window in the whole of Morpeth. Yeavering Bell N/A Twin-peaked hill that houses remains to the largest Iron Age hillfort in the region. Yeavering Bell forms a part of the Cheviots Hills as it lies just at the very edge of the rolling hills. The hills have been suggested to be site of religious importance in the Iron Age. The walk up the hill can be quite strenuous due to the elevation, however the views on top of the hill are extremely attractive to visitors of the range. While walking up the hill, visitors may see the remains of stone huts and, if lucky, a herd of wild goats grazing. The summit is almost 1200 feet above sea level and surrounded by a prehistoric stone wall and its name comes from the Saxon site of Yeavering which the summit overlooks. Whitehouse Farm 1997 AD Farm centre that features a wide variety of traditional and exotic animals for all ages to visit. Whitehouse Farm is Northumberland\'s largest family run farm attraction, spreading over 40 acres. The farm features a large collection of animals including traditional farm animals and more exotic species. On the site, there are also many child-friendly attractions such as pedal tractors, go-karts and other playground facilities, while indoors there is a safe play section for younger children. The farm itself used to be one of the biggest producers of eggs in the region, originally starting out as a Chicken Farm. Their roots of home grown food are still present through the Whitehouse Farm Kitchen, where visitors can buy food throughout the day and meet fellow tourists. Newcastle Helix 2016 AD An exemplar project in urban development in the digital age, Newcastle Helix is comprised of world leaders in science, technology and research. Originally Science Central, Newcastle Helix is “the only city centre quarter of its kind in the UK” and is home to multi-million pound sites such as the Urban Sciences Building and the upcoming National Innovation Centre for Data. The Helix is situated amidst new affordable student accommodation and is only minutes away from Newcastle city centre, along with shops galore within intu Eldon Square. Costing around £350 million from a joint partnership between Newcastle City Council and the University, Newcastle Helix aims to promote first class education and research in a futuristic environment, alongside a flourishing commercial and residential city.
